titlestmt.titleproper: The Henry Darwin Didama MD Collection
titlestmt.subtitle: An inventory of the collection at the SUNY Upstate Medical University Health Sciences Library
titlestmt.author: Nicole R. Topich

publicationstmt.publisher: Archives and Special Collections at the SUNY Upstate Health Sciences Library

did.head: Overview of the Collection
did.unittitle: The Henry Darwin Didama MD Collection
did.abstract: This collection contains the papers of Henry Darwin Didama, who became a Professor of Clinical Medicine at the Syracuse University College of Medicine in 1872 and Dean of the College of Medicine beginning in 1888. The collection has five series: Writings, Printed Materials, Photographs, Subject Files, and Memorabilia.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Henry Darwin Didama (1823-1905) was born in Perryville on June 17, 1823. His father and grandfather, John and Simon Didama, came from Delft, Holland with the Holland Company to settle in Trenton, NY and both worked as doctors. Henry attended Cazenovia Seminary and was a teacher during the winter of 1840-1841. He began practicing medicine in the office of Doctor David A. Moore of Cazenovia and continued under Doctor Nelson A. Powers of Syracuse. He studied at the Geneva College of Medicine and the Albany Medical School, the latter of which he graduated from in 1846 at the age of 23. He then settled in Romulus, where he remained for 5 years and studied under Enos Smith Vail. At this time, he met and married Sarah Miller, the daughter of Honorable Sherman Miller. Henry came to Syracuse in 1851, and in 1874 he bought the Wescott homestead on South Salina Street and made that his office and home for the remainder of his life. The family had three children; Henry Darwin Jr., who died in infancy; Sherman, who died when a medical student; and Amelia, who married William M. Niven and completed a medical course at Syracuse and assisted her father, but died in 1893 from typhoid fever in Florida.

With the establishment of the Medical College in 1872, he was elected as Professor of Clinical Medicine, and in 1873, he was made Professor of the Principles and Practice of Medicine and Clinical Medicine, which he served as until his resignation in 1893. After the death of Dean Frederick Hyde in 1888, he was elected Dean of the College of Medicine and received the degree of LL.D. from Syracuse University that same year. In 1894, he was elected Trustee at Large of Syracuse University, which he served as until his death. In addition, he wrote under the nom de plume Amos Cottle about his observations of foreign customs and people in letters to the local press. He most notably served as president of the Onondaga County Medical Society, the Syracuse City Medical Society, the Central New York Medical Association, the Medical Society of the State of New York, the New York Medical Association, and the Syracuse Academy of Medicine, and Vice President of the American Medical Association before his death on October 4, 1905.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the papers of Henry Darwin Didama, who became a Professor of Clinical Medicine at the Syracuse University College of Medicine in 1872 and Dean of the College of Medicine beginning in 1888. There are five series in this collection.
Writings: this series contains the original and typed transcription of Henry Darwin Didama’s diary entitled “Private Journal of the Affairs du Vie, 1842-1852.”
Printed materials: these documents include printed materials from and about Henry Darwin Didama from 1875 to 1906.

Photographs: these materials are portrait photographs of Henry Darwin Didama and correspondence from 1944 on the donation of two portrait photographs from R.W.S. Vail of Albany, the grandchild of Enos Smith Vail of Romulus.
Subject Files: this contains one folder with information on Henry Darwin Didama.
Memorabilia: these documents consist of certifications, membership, and diplomas.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: The Henry Darwin Didama MD Collection has been arranged into five series.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: There are no access restrictions on this material.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Written permission must be obtained from the Archives and Special Collections of the SUNY Upstate Health Sciences Library and all relevant rights holders before publishing quotations, excerpts or images from any materials in this collection.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation for this material is as follows:
The Henry Darwin Didama MD Collection, Archives and Special Collections in the Health Sciences Library, SUNY Upstate Medical University

did.unittitle: Printed Materials
The Model Physician. A Valedictory Address, Delivered in Wieting Hall, Syracuse, February 19th, 1875. By Henry D. Didama.
Tubercular Consumption: Introduction to a Discussion at the New York State Medical Association, November, 1886. By H.D. Didama.
Tubercular Consumption: Is it Ever Inherited? Read at the Second Annual Meeting of the New York State Medical Association, November, 1885. By Henry D. Didama.
Anniversary Address, Before the Medical Society of the State of New York, At its Seventy-Fourth Annual Meeting, by H.D. Didama.
Henry Darwin Didama. By John L. Heffron. From the New York State Journal of Medicine, October, 1906.
Memoranda, Practical and Suggestive. (a) Early Aspiration in Pleuritis. (b) Mineral Waters, Crude and Refined. (c) Coughing Made Easy in Bronchiectasis. (d) The Insurance Sponge. By H.D. Didama.
Conservative Progress. First Annual Address to the New York State Medical Association, Delivered in New York, November 18, 1884, by Henry D. Didama.

Photocopy of Inaugural Address, Delivered February 3d, 1880, at the Opening of the Seventy-Fourth Annual Meeting. By the President, Henry Darwin Didama. From the Transactions of the Medical Society of the State of New York.
The Ideal Physician. By Henry D. Didama.
Photographs
Portrait photographs of Henry Darwin Didama and correspondence from 1944 on the donation of two portrait photographs from R.W.S. Vail of Albany, the grandchild of Enos Smith Vail of Romulus.
Subject Files

Documents concerning Henry Darwin Didama, including a typed partial bibliography of his writings from 1958, an undated article from the Medical Book News quoting Dr. Didama, a photocopy of a newspaper clipping on Dr. Didama’s funeral services, and a note to Miss Bond from Henry Darwin Didama to post a notice that surgery will be omitted from the second year so that the first and second year can focus on the fundamental branches and pathology and the third and fourth years can focus on the practical application.
Memorabilia

Membership certifications to the New York State Medical Association, the British Medical Association, the Onondaga Medical Society, the Gynaecological Society of Boston, the New York State Medical Association, and the American Medical Association.
Certification of attendance for course the Surgical Diseases of Women in Boston from Horatio R. Storer with portrait photograph.
Albany Medical College diploma.
Certification of appointment as colonel of the 6th division of the National Guard in the state of New York.
Certification from the American Medical Association as representative to the International Medical Congress.
Certification as founder and fellow of the New York State Medical Association.
Ticket, invitation, program, and menu for dinner given in honor of Dean Henry Darwin Didama on the occasion of his fiftieth anniversary as a practitioner of medicine.
